newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong, Philippines reach air service agreement.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong, Philippines reach air service agreement.

text.p: Hong Kong and the Philippines have initialled an Air Services Agreement, the last to be finalised before the British colony is handed back to China next year, the government said on Thursday.
The agreement reached on Wednesday would be submitted to the Sino-British Joint Liaison Group (JLG) for endorsement before it can be formally signed by Hong Kong, it said in a statement.

"With the successful conclusion of the talks on the Hong Kong/Philippines air service agreement, Hong Kong has now completed negotiations on separating its air services from those of the UK in preparation for the change of sovereignty in 1997."
The two sides further agreed on an expansionary traffic rights arrangement provinding for increased services between Hong Kong and the Philippines, the statement said.
The Hong Kong/Philippines air service negotation had been dragging on for six years. The government statement did not give details on the initialled agreement.

It said Hong Kong had signed 13 air service agreements and arrangements and was now in hand to sign four more agreements which had received clearance by the Joint Liaison Group, the diplomatic body overseeing Hong Kong's handover.
Michael Arnold, Hong Kong's chief negotiator, said his next immediate task would be the negotiation of overflight agreements following JLG clearance in September.

Overflight agreements are needed with a number of countries which Hong Kong airlines overfly on their key intercontinental routes and with which Hong Kong has not previously negotiated on Air Services Agreement.
